importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when the LEAP trial results were published and initial public health guidelines for early peanut introduction were issued, marking a turning point in allergy prevention practices.
When expanded guidelines for early allergen introduction were issued, leading to a significant drop in peanut allergy diagnoses among children.
The year when updated medical guidance was finalized, recommending the introduction of peanuts and other allergens between 4 and 6 months of age without prior screening.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The decade-long period from 2015 to 2025 during which the implementation of early peanut introduction guidelines has led to measurable declines in peanut allergy rates.

keyTakeAways: Peanut allergy rates in U.S. children aged 0 to 3 declined by over 27% after 2015 and over 40% after 2017 due to early allergen introduction guidelines.
Approximately 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies since 2015, compared to earlier estimates of 60,000 (corrected in the article).

The landmark LEAP trial, led by Dr. Gideon Lack at King’s College London, showed that early introduction of peanuts reduced allergy risk by more than 80% and persisted in about 70% of children into adolescence.
Despite the strong scientific evidence, adoption of early introduction practices among medical professionals was slow: only 29% of pediatricians and 65% of allergists followed the 2017 guidelines.
Current guidance from the American Academy of Pediatrics and other health bodies recommends introducing peanuts and other allergens between 4 and 6 months of age, without testing or screening.
Safe methods include small amounts of peanut butter, milk-based yogurt, soy-based yogurt, and tree nut butters, under pediatrician supervision.
Advocacy groups like Food Allergy Research & Education (FARE) support early introduction as a public health strategy to reduce food allergy incidence and prevalence.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His 2015 LEAP trial provided the scientific foundation for new public health recommendations on early allergen introduction.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The LEAP trial was conducted at King’s College London and is central to the origin of the evidence-based guidelines for early peanut introduction.

namedEntities.name: Dr. David Hill
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Allergist and researcher at Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia, author of a 2025 study analyzing health records.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He led a study analyzing real-world health data to demonstrate that early allergen introduction has made a measurable public health impact.

namedEntities.name: Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the institutional base for the research that analyzed pediatric health records to track changes in food allergy diagnoses over time.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: FARE supports early allergen introduction as a proven strategy and publicly endorses the updated medical guidelines.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A decade after a landmark study showed that early introduction of peanuts to infants reduces the risk of developing peanut allergies, new research confirms that this public health strategy has made a measurable impact. Since the 2015 LEAP trial and subsequent guidelines, peanut allergy rates in U.S. children aged 0 to 3 have declined by over 27% and over 40% after 2017. Data from electronic health records show that about 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies since 2015, with early allergen introduction now widely supported by medical experts and advocacy groups. Despite initial slow adoption—only 29% of pediatricians and 65% of allergists followed the updated guidelines—current recommendations from the American Academy of Pediatrics and other bodies advocate for introducing peanuts and other allergens between 4 and 6 months of age without screening. Experts like Dr. David Hill and Dr. Gideon Lack emphasize that small, safe exposures to peanut products are effective and supported by science, helping to reduce the prevalence of a dangerous, life-threatening condition.
title: Early Peanut Introduction in Infants Reduces Allergy Rates in U.S. Children
